This week's structure readout for Ops compares normalized postings, wage, and demand proxies so that units do not dominate the signals. The variance index is 0.40, up versus last week, where lower values imply compression and higher values imply dispersion. Average absolute correlation is 0.47 with velocity at 0.09, capturing whether alignment across signals is accelerating or fading. Together this suggests signals show mixed alignment with no sharp regime shift.

Cluster stability is 0.71, meaning clusters shifted modestly. Rolling correlations are moderate, suggesting how tightly groups of signals are moving together in the latest window. This week no synchronization event is flagged under the current thresholds.

These results are descriptive and conservative, built from weekly aggregates and simple normalization. They highlight where independent data starts to move together, not why it happens. No prediction. Pattern-only. Correlation ≠ causation.

This week's structure readout for Finance compares normalized postings, wage, and demand proxies so that units do not dominate the signals. The variance index is 0.29, steady versus last week, where lower values imply compression and higher values imply dispersion. Average absolute correlation is 0.40 with velocity at -0.05, capturing whether alignment across signals is accelerating or fading. Together this suggests signals show mixed alignment with no sharp regime shift.

Cluster stability is 0.81, meaning cluster memberships held steady. Rolling correlations are moderate, suggesting how tightly groups of signals are moving together in the latest window. This week no synchronization event is flagged under the current thresholds.

These results are descriptive and conservative, built from weekly aggregates and simple normalization. They highlight where independent data starts to move together, not why it happens. No prediction. Pattern-only. Correlation ≠ causation.

This week's structure readout for Tech compares normalized postings, wage, and demand proxies so that units do not dominate the signals. The variance index is 0.29, down versus last week, where lower values imply compression and higher values imply dispersion. Average absolute correlation is 0.37 with velocity at 0.04, capturing whether alignment across signals is accelerating or fading. Together this suggests signals are compressing as dispersion falls and alignment strengthens.

Cluster stability is 1.00, meaning cluster memberships held steady. Rolling correlations are soft, suggesting how tightly groups of signals are moving together in the latest window. This week no synchronization event is flagged under the current thresholds.

These results are descriptive and conservative, built from weekly aggregates and simple normalization. They highlight where independent data starts to move together, not why it happens. No prediction. Pattern-only. Correlation ≠ causation.
